questions.text: Which of the following pathological changes is represented by the marked structure seen on histopathology of a liver specimen?
questions.solution:
The above histopathological image shows Councilman or acidophil bodies. They represent hepatocytes undergoing apoptosis.

Councilman bodies are commonly seen in acute viral hepatitis.

questions.text: A pathologist is examining a liver biopsy specimen from a patient with liver disease. The following finding is noted. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this finding?
questions.solution:
The given histopathological image shows hepatic macro-vesicular steatosis along with intraparenchymal cholestasis, which is suggestive of fatty liver. This condition can occur due to alcoholism.

The lipid accumulates in the hepatocytes as vacuoles. These vacuoles have a clear appearance on hematoxylin and eosin staining.

A few causes of fatty liver are as follows:

  • Alcoholism - most common cause in developed countries
  • Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) - associated with diabetes and obesity
  • Toxins
  • Malnutrition
  • Dyslipidemia
  • Anoxia

Fatty change is mostly seen in the liver because it is the major organ involved in fat metabolism. It may also occur in the heart, muscles, and kidneys.

The most common form of lipid accumulation is triglycerides. Other forms of lipid that can be accumulated include cholesterol, cholesterol esters, and phospholipids.

questions.text: A 19-year-old boy presented with a single painless papule on his penis with no enlarged lymph nodes. A smear was made from the lesion and stained with Wright- Giemsa stain which showed the finding as shown in the following picture. Identify the organism.
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the image showing Donovan bodies in Wright/Giemsa-stained impression smears indicate a diagnosis of donovanosis caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. They appear as rounded coccobacilli within cystic spaces in large mononuclear cells (called Pund cells).

Klebsiella granulomatis shows bipolar condensation of chromatin giving a safety pin appearance.

Bipolar staining (safety pin appearance) is shown by:

  • H. ducreyi
  • Vibrio parahaemolyticus
  • Klebsiella granulomatis
  • Yersinia pestis
  • Burkholderia pseudomallei
  • Burkholderia mallei

Related Pearl: Comparison of Genital Ulcers

  Genital herpes  Syphilitic chancre (Hard chancre) Donovanosis/ granuloma inguinale Chancroid (soft chancre) LGV
Incubation period 2-7 days

10-90 days 

Average: 21days

 1-12 weeks 1-14 days 3 days - 6 weeks
Causative agent HSV-2>HSV-1 Treponema pallidum Klebsiella granulomatis Hemophilus ducreyi

Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1,L2,L3
Clinical presentation

Cluster of vesicles on erythematous base.

Painful and pruritic lymphadenopathy

Single painless ulcer with a clean base and a firm raised border.

Painless lymphadenopathy

Painless papule or nodule erodes into beefy red granulomatous ulcer with rolled edges.

No lymphadenopathy, pseudobubos are seen

Painful ulcer (ducreyi makes you cry).

Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy

Painless genital ulcer.

Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy
Diagnosis  Tzanck preparation shows multinucleated giant cells, PCR Clinical diagnosis Donovan bodies on biopsy Clinical diagnosis Nucleic acid amplification tests
Treatment Acyclovir/famcyclovir or valacyclovir Penicillin/Ceftriaxone

Azithromycin/Doxycycline

questions.text: Endoscopic and barium swallow images of a lesion in the oesophagus of a patient are as shown below. What is the expected histopathological finding?
questions.solution: The given images showing an esophageal exophytic growth on endoscopy and apple core appearance in the middle 1/3 of the esophagus on barium swallow are suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma. The characteristic histopathological finding in this condition are nests of stratified malignant cells and keratin pearls, which are noted in image 4.

questions.text: The stain used for melanin in the below image is
questions.solution:
The stain used for melanin in the above image is Masson Fontana stain. Other stains for melanin are Schmorl’s method and an enzyme histochemical method called DOPA oxidase method. This DOPA oxidase method is the most specific stain for melanin.

Other options:

  • Oil red stains neutral lipids and fatty acids
  • PAS stains glycogen, mucin, mucoprotein, glycoproteins and fungi
  • Gomori methamine stains fungi

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in Pathology and Microbiology

Staining technique Cells/inclusions stained Disorders
H&E Most common stain used in routine histopathology Commonly used for all slides
Papanicolaou stain Universal stain for cytological preparations Cytological studies
PAS Demonstrate glycogen, mucin, fungi, macrophages  Whipple's disease, adenocarcinomas, and glycogen-positive tumors (Ewings sarcoma, renal cell carcinoma)
PTAH (Phosphotungstic acid hematoxylin) Fibrin Gliosis, Ependymomas, Tumours of skeletal muscles, Fibrin deposits
Alcian blue For acid mucins: Positive stain for mucins of the intestinal mucosa and negative stain for mucins of gastric mucosa and Brunner's gland Barrett's esophagus, Gastric disorders
Perl's Prussian blue Demonstrate hemosiderin and iron Hemochromatosis 
Masson–Fontana stain Demonstrate melanin Nevus and malignant melanoma
von Kossa method Demonstrate calcium Calcification of tissues
Van Gieson stain

Demonstrate collagen in; Differentiate amyloid from collagen

 Spindle-cell neoplasm; Delineate extent of fibrosis 
Masson trichrome stain Demonstrate collagen and muscle Connective tissue disorders, muscle and fibroblast tumors, liver cirrhosis, neuromuscular diseases 
Reticulin stain Demonstrate reticulin fibers Distinguish epithelial from non-epithelial neoplasm, Hodgkin's lymphoma, early cirrhosis of the liver, myelofibrosis
Verhoeff's method Demonstrate elastic fibers Malignant hypertension, arteriovenous malformation aneurysms, Marfan's syndrome, emphysema lung
Oil red O Sudan Black Sudan III/IV Demonstrate fat/lipids Fatty liver-fat embolism-fibroma vs. thecoma of the ovary-liposarcoma 

Microbiology stains:

Stain  Uses
Ziehl–Neelsen Stain Mycobacteria (all species, including Mycobacterium leprae), Nocardia spp. Cyst of Cryptosporidium parvum, Isospora spp., and Cyclospora spp., Head of sperms

questions.text: You are investigating an outbreak of diarrhea.  You find out that the etiological agent causes stacked-brick formation on hep-2 cells as shown below.  What is the likely organism?
questions.solution:
The stacked-brick pattern of adherence on hep-2 cells is caused by enteroaggregative E. coli (EAEC).

Enteroaggregative E. coli has been associated with persistent diarrhea. Intestinal colonization of EAEC is mediated by aggregative adherence fimbriae (AAF). EAST-1 toxin (enteroaggregative heat-stable toxin) is considered to be a major virulence factor for EAEC.

The given image shows the stacked-brick pattern of adherence on microscopy at 600x magnification.

questions.text: You are examining the peripheral smear of a patient with anaemia and see the following finding. Name the finding and its pathogenesis.

choices.text: Howell Jolly body - ineffective RBC enucleation

questions.solution:
The marked structure in this peripheral smear showing figure of 8 appearance is a Cabot ring. They are RBC inclusion bodies seen in conditions due to ineffective erythropoiesis. It is considered a remnant of microtubules during cell division.

Cabot rings can be seen in the following conditions:

  • Megaloblastic anaemia
  • Post-splenectomy patients
  • Lead poisoning
  • Hemolytic anemias 

Option A: Heinz bodies are due to oxidative damage, seen in G6PD deficiency.

Option B: Basophilic stippling is due to ribosomal precipitation, seen in heavy metal poisoning, thalassemia and sickle cell disease.

Option D: Howell Jolly bodies are due to ineffective RBC enucleation, characteristic of asplenia.

questions.text: Identify the organism.
questions.solution:
The given image shows Treponema pallidum demonstrated by dark ground microscopy. 

Treponemes are short and slender with regular and sharp spirals. 

Other options:

Option A: Leptospira have a large number of closely wound spirals and characteristic hooked ends as shown in the image below

Option C: Borrelia are large with irregular and wide open coils.

Option D: Helicobacter pylori is a spiral rod (bacilli) that is not classified as a spirochete.

questions.text: The peripheral smear of a patient with anaemia, jaundice and splenomegaly shows pincer cells. Which protein deficiency is responsible for this finding?
questions.solution: Pincer cell or mushroom cell is seen in hereditary spherocytosis associated with deficiency of cytoskeletal protein band 3.

questions.text: An adolescent male patient presents with fatigue. His total leucocyte count is 138 x 10^9 / L with 80% blasts on the peripheral smear. Chest X-ray shows a large mediastinal mass. The bone marrow aspirate is as shown below. What would the immunophenotyping of this patient’s blasts most likely demonstrate?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and bone marrow aspirate are suggestive of  T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Thus, immunophenotyping of the blasts would demonstrate an immature T-cell phenotype (Tdt/CD34/CD7 positive).

The bone marrow aspirate shows lymphoblast with condensed nuclear chromatin, small inconspicuous nucleoli, and scanty cytoplasm lacking granules. 

ALL is usually seen in adolescent boys with thymic involvement in 50% to 70%. It has an abrupt stormy onset, within days to a few weeks of the first symptoms.

Clinical features of ALL include: 

  • Bone marrow failure - anemia, fever, infections, bleeding
  • Mass effects due to neoplastic infiltration - bone pain, generalized lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, hepatomegaly, and testicular enlargement
  • CNS manifestations - headache, vomiting, and nerve palsies 
  • B-ALL - Pancytopenia due to marrow involvement
  • T-ALL - Mediastinal mass, compression of  large vessels and airways in the mediastinum, lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly

Related Pearl: Immunophenotyping of Acute Lymphocytic Leukemia (ALL)

Type of ALL  Immunophenotype 
Early Pre-B ALL  TdT, DR, CD19, CD24 
Pre B ALL  TdT, DR, CD10, CD19, CD20, CD24, Cy Ig 
Common ALL  CD19+,  CD10+/CALLA+ 
Mature B  ALL  DR, CD19, CD20, CD24, Surface Ig 
Pro-T ALL   CD3, CD7 
Pre-T ALL  TdT, CD2, CD3, CD4, CD5, CD7, CD8, CD34 
Mature T ALL  CD2, CD7, Tdt

questions.text: Identify the dermatophyte based on the macroconidia shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The above image shows multicellular, pear-shaped macroconidia, arranged in clusters, seen in genus Epidermophyton.

Related Pearl: Characteristic features of macroconidia and microconidia of dermatophytes

Dermatophyte  

Macroconidia

Microconidia

Trichophyton

Thin-walled, pencil-shaped

Small unicellular

Microsporum

Multicellular, spindle-shaped

Scanty

Epidermophyton

Multicellular, pear-shaped, arranged in clusters

Absent

Trichophyton

 

Microsporum

 

Epidermophyton

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with painless generalized lymphadenopathy and weakness. Lymph node biopsy shows the following picture. Which of the following is not true for this condition?

choices.text: Possible transformation into diffuse large B-cell lymphoma

questions.solution:
The lymph biopsy shows closely packed back-to-back follicles of variable areas and very less inter-follicular area. It is suggestive of follicular lymphoma.

Follicular lymphoma usually follows an indolent waxing and waning course, not an aggressive course.

Lymph node (LN) biopsy shows a nodular pattern with centrocytes and centroblasts as shown below.

Immunophenotyping:

  • The cell of origin is germinal-center B cell, so it is positive for CD19, CD20, CD10, BCL6, and surface Ig.
  • BCL2 expression is positive in over 90% of cases.

Histologic transformation to diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) occurs in 30 to 50% of cases.

Note: In contrast to follicular lymphoma, DLBCL has an aggressive course, shows a diffuse pattern of growth in lymph node biopsy and shows BCL-6 positivity.

questions.text: The peripheral smear of a patient diagnosed with multiple myeloma is shown below. What does the marked structure contain?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a Mott cell which is a plasma cell with globular cytoplasmic inclusions containing immunoglobulins called Russell bodies.

Inclusions containing Ig are frequently seen in the cytoplasm (Russell bodies) or the nucleus (Dutcher bodies) of some of the plasma cells in myeloma.

Related Pearl: Pathological Cells/Bodies in Multiple Myeloma

  • Dutcher bodies - pale-staining, PAS-positive intranuclear inclusions within plasma cells containing Ig, which are more common in IgA myeloma (Image below). 

Russell bodies - They are globular intracellular accumulations of immunoglobulins (Ig). Russell bodies are distended endoplasmic reticulum. Plasma cells filled with multiple Russell bodies are called Mott cells.

  • Flame cells - Plasma cells with fiery red cytoplasm due to vermillion-staining, glycogen-rich IgA in cytoplasmic projections

questions.text: A wet mount examination of the stool sample of a patient with abdominal pain and diarrhea is given below.  Which of the following parasites is he likely infected with?
questions.solution:
The given image showing an operculated egg (egg having a lid-like structure on its end) in the stool sample is suggestive of Fasciola hepatica infection.

The eggs of Fasciola hepatica are large, ovoid, operculated, and bile stained. They contain an immature larva (miracidium) and do not float in the saturated salt solution.

The following are the parasites with operculated eggs:

  • Fasciola hepatica
  • Fasciolopsis buski
  • Fasciola gigantica
  • Paragonimus westermani
  • Opisthorchis felineus
  • Clonorchis sinensis
  • Gastrodiscoides hominis
  • Diphyllobothrium latum

Eggs of Schistosoma japonicum, Enterobius vermicularis, and Ancylostoma duodenale are non-operculated. 

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: A 73-year-old woman presents with chronic fatigue and easy bruising. She has had surgery for ovarian cancer 7 years ago along with chemoradiation. Her lab reports reveal pancytopenia and bone marrow biopsy shows the following finding. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of therapy-related myelodysplastic syndrome (t-MDS).

The bone marrow biopsy stained with Perl's Prussian blue shows ringed sideroblasts. They are erythroblasts with iron-laden mitochondria visible as perinuclear granules as shown in the image below.

Myelodysplastic syndrome is a group of clonal stem cell disorders characterized by maturation defects, associated with ineffective hematopoiesis.

It is of two types:

  • Primary MDS - develops slowly, usually after 50 years of age.
  • Secondary or therapy-related MDS (t-MDS) - develops 2 to 8 years after toxic drug or radiation exposure with poor prognosis

Patients usually present with weakness, infections and hemorrhages due to pancytopenia. Both types of MDS have a high risk of transformation to acute myeloid leukemia (AML). However, most frequent and rapid transformation occurs in therapy-related MDS (t-MDS).

VEXAS syndrome (vacuoles, E1 enzyme, X-linked, autoinflammatory, somatic) is a Novel disorder discovered in 2020. It is an adult-onset inflammatory disease with clinical features that bridge rheumatologic & hematologic conditions. VEXAS may be a prototype for new class of “hematoinflammatory diseases.” These diseases would be defined by somatic mutations in hematopoietic cells, systemic inflammation, & potential to evolve into overt myelodysplastic, myeloproliferative, or lymphoproliferative disease.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man admitted to ICU develops sepsis 3 days after insertion of a central venous catheter. A peripheral blood smear reveals the following. What does the structure marked by the arrow indicate?
questions.solution:
The given peripheral smear, prepared from an individual with bacterial sepsis, shows reactive changes in neutrophils. The arrow-marked structure is a Döhle body.

Reactive changes in neutrophils associated with leukocytosis in severe inflammatory disorders are:

  • Toxic granules, which are coarser and darker than the normal neutrophilic granules, represent abnormal azurophilic (primary) granules
  • Döhle bodies are patches of the dilated endoplasmic reticulum that appear as sky-blue cytoplasmic puddles
  • Toxic cytoplasmic vacuoles 

The image given below shows a neutrophil with cytoplasmic vacuoles.

questions.text: The type of epithelium as shown in the image below is present in ______.
questions.solution:
The type of epithelium shown in the image is the transitional epithelium and it is present in the urinary bladder.

Transitional epithelium is a specialized epithelium lining most of the urinary tract, hence it is also called the urothelium. The deepest layer consists of columnar or cuboidal cells, and the middle layer consists of polyhedral or pear-shaped cells. The surface layer consists of large, polypoid, dome-shaped, or umbrella-shaped cells. As the epithelium gets stretched to accommodate urine, the surface cells become flattened. The cells are called transitional due to this apparent change (transition) from stratified cuboidal epithelium in a relaxed state to stratified squamous epithelium when it is stretched.

They are present in:

  • Collecting ducts
  • Renal pelvis and calyces
  • Ureter
  • Urinary bladder
  • Pre-prostatic and prostatic parts of urethra

questions.text: The following histological image depicts a pathology in which of the following sites?
questions.solution:
The given histopathological image shows benign papillary projections covered with columnar secretory epithelium and underlying myoepithelial cells. These are commonly seen in papillary hidradenoma of the vulva.

It presents as a sharply circumscribed nodule, most commonly on the labia majora or interlabial folds. Like the breast, the vulva also contains modified apocrine sweat glands. Its histologic appearance is identical to that of intraductal papilloma of the breast.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding papillary carcinoma of the thyroid is incorrect?

choices.text: It is the most common form of thyroid carcinoma
Diagnosis can be made based on nuclear features, even in the absence of typical architecture
It is associated with previous exposure to ionizing radiation

questions.solution:
Hematogenous spread is rare in papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. Metastases to lymph nodes are more commonly associated with this condition.

It is associated with previous exposure to ionizing radiation. The presence of nuclear features such as Orphan Annie eye nuclei (empty-appearing nuclei) are diagnostic, regardless of papillary architecture.

Related Pearl: Papillary thyroid carcinoma

Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid carcinoma. It is most common in iodine sufficient areas, children and in those exposed to ionizing radiation. 

The mean age of presentation is 3rd-4th decade and is more common in women than men (2:1). Dysphagia, dysphonia and dyspnea are associated with local invasion.

It usually presents as a cold nodule on the scan. Histological findings include:

  • Branching papillae 
  • Follicles with the fibrovascular stalk
  • Psammoma bodies
  • Nuclear changes- 
    • Optically clear - Ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei
    • Pseudo-inclusions
    • Nuclear grooves.

Lymph node metastasis is common. Lateral aberrant thyroid denotes a cervical lymph node invaded by papillary carcinoma. The most common sites of metastasis : lung > liver > bone > brain.

It has an excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male with skin-colored umbilicated papules. Microscopy is as shown below. The most likely diagnosis is______.
questions.solution:
The given microscopic image shows large, ellipsoid, homogeneous, cytoplasmic inclusion in cells of the stratum granulosum and the stratum corneum classically seen in molluscum contagiosum.

Molluscum contagiosum is a common, self-limited viral disease of the skin caused by a poxvirus. Poxvirus is brick-shaped and is about 300 nm in size, the largest pathogenic poxvirus in humans

Tzanck smear shows intracytoplasmic molluscum bodies (Henderson–Patterson bodies), the largest known inclusion bodies (30–35 μm).

Individual lesions are firm, pruritic, pink to skin-colored umbilicated papules (shown below). A curd-like material can be expressed from the central umbilication

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a 1-month history of pain in the left knee, which is tender on palpation. X-ray shows a 5 cm mass in the distal femoral epiphysis, with a soap bubble appearance. Microscopy is as seen below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of osteoclastoma/ giant-cell tumor (GCT) of bone.

GCT is a relatively uncommon benign, but locally aggressive, neoplasm that usually arises in individuals in their 20s to 40s. The neoplastic cells express high levels of RANKL. It promotes the proliferation of osteoclast precursors and their differentiation into mature osteoclasts via RANK expressed by these cells.

GCTs arise in the epiphysis but may extend into the metaphysis. The majority arise around the knee (distal femur and proximal tibia). Most are solitary, multicentric tumors in the distal extremities. The tumors destroy the overlying cortex, producing a bulging soft tissue mass delineated by a thin shell of reactive tissue.

Histopathologically, sheets of uniform oval mononuclear cells and numerous osteoclast-type giant cells are seen with 100 or more nuclei. Necrosis and mitotic activity may be prominent.

The image given below shows the histopathological findings seen in osteoclastoma.

Typically, they are treated with curettage, but 40% to 60% recur locally.

Up to 4% of tumors metastasize to the lungs, but these sometimes spontaneously regress and they are rarely fatal. The RANKL inhibitor, denosumab, has shown promise as adjuvant therapy in GCT.

 Note: The E mnemonic for GCT:

  • Epiphyseal
  • Eccentric
  • Egg-shell crackling
  • Expansile

questions.text: A 35-year-old immunocompromised patient presented with fever, headache, and neurological deficits. MRI showed multiple enhancing lesions and a stereotactic biopsy of the lesion was done. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows lymphocytes, macrophages and eosinophils surrounding the toxoplasma bradyzoites encased in cysts. Along with the case scenario, the most likely diagnosis is cerebral toxoplasmosis.

Cerebral toxoplasmosis is an opportunistic infection commonly found in the setting of HIV-associated immunosuppression. Toxoplasmosis of the CNS produces brain abscesses, which are found most often in the cerebral cortex (near the grey-white junction) and deep gray nuclei.

Lesions of acute cerebral toxoplasmosis exhibit central necrosis, petechial haemorrhages surrounded by acute and chronic inflammation, macrophage infiltration, and vascular proliferation. Both free tachyzoites and encysted bradyzoites may be found at the periphery of the necrotic foci. Chronic lesions consist of small cystic spaces containing scattered lipid and hemosiderin-laden macrophages that are surrounded by gliotic brain.

Option A: In cerebral malaria caused by P. falciparum, brain vessels are plugged with parasitized red cells. Around the vessels, ring hemorrhages and small focal inflammatory reactions (called malarial or Dürck granulomata) are seen.

Option C: Herpes simplex encephalitis is necrotizing and often hemorrhagic. Cowdry type A intranuclear viral inclusion bodies may be found in both neurons and glia.

Option D: Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) is an encephalitis caused by the JC polyomavirus. The disease occurs almost exclusively in immunosuppressed individuals. The virus preferentially infects oligodendrocytes and hence demyelin­ation is its principal pathologic effect. The enlarged oligodendrocyte nuclei contain glassy amphophilic viral inclusions.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with a pearly papule over the face containing prominent dilated subepidermal blood vessels and surface ulceration. A histological picture of the tumor is shown below. All are true about the tumor except:

choices.text: Incidence is increased in xeroderma pigmentosum
Presence of multiple such tumors is seen in Gorlin syndrome

questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and histology are suggestive of basal cell carcinoma (BCC). It is a locally aggressive cutaneous tumor, and metastasis is very rare.

It occurs in sun-exposed areas with increased incidence in the setting of immunosuppression and in disorders of DNA repair, such as xeroderma pigmentosum.

BCCs usually present as pearly papules and locally invasive ulcers (rodent ulcers). Histologically, the tumor cells resemble those in the normal basal cell layer of the epidermis with peripheral palisading and retraction cleft.

It is associated with mutations that activate the hedgehog pathway signaling.

Gorlin syndrome is an autosomal-dominant disorder with multiple basal cell carcinomas, medulloblastomas, ovarian fibromas, and odontogenic keratocysts, pits of the palms, and soles.

The image below shows the histopathology of BCC.

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for arteriolar wall thickening in hyaline arteriosclerosis?
questions.solution:
The arteriolar wall thickening in hyaline arteriosclerosis occurs as a result of plasma protein deposition.

Hyaline arteriosclerosis occurs due to injury to the endothelial cells. This allows plasma protein leakage into the arteriolar wall. The endothelial injury also stimulates increased matrix synthesis by the smooth muscle cells. These lead to the deposition of homogenous pink hyaline material causing the thickening of arteriolar walls.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man from the eastern part of India presents with a shallow and slowly expanding ulcer with heaped-up borders over the face. Biopsy reveals granulomas and the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows many histiocytes containing Leishman–Donovan bodies and surrounding chronic inflammatory cells classically seen in cutaneous leishmaniasis.

Cutaneous leishmaniasis presents with a shallow and slowly expanding ulcer, often with heaped-up borders.

On microscopic examination, the lesion shows granulomatous inflammation, usually with many giant cells and few parasites.

Diffuse cutaneous leishmaniasis is characterized by a single skin nodule, which continues spreading until the entire body is covered by nodular lesions. Microscopically, they contain aggregates of foamy macrophages stuffed with leishmania.
